p: However, ours is hardly the only era to face such tribulations. Deadly pandemics and large-scale epidemics have challenged human existence throughout history ( Table 1) ( 2). While these crises were once separated by centuries, or at least many decades, they are now becoming much more common. Since 2003, we have experienced severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) (a near pandemic), an influenza pandemic (H1N1pdm in 2009), a chikungunya pandemic (2014), a Zika pandemic (2015), and a widespread pandemic-like extension of Ebola over five African countries, with cases exported globally (2014 to 2015). Although the meaning of the word “pandemic” has recently been reinterpreted according to differing agendas ( 3, 4), it seems clear that we now live in an era of pandemics, newly emerging infectious diseases, and the return of old contagious foes.
